node.title: Aaron Rodgers Lashes Out About N.F.L.’s Vaccine Requirements
node.alt: Green Bay Packers quarterback Aaron Rodgers, who tested positive for the coronavirus and is not vaccinated, criticized the N.F.L.’s virus protocols and said that some of the rules are “based purely in trying to out and shame people.”
node.description: In a bizarre interview the quarterback conducted while quarantining because of a positive coronavirus test, he said that he was a victim of a “woke mob” and that he had unsuccessfully petitioned the N.F.L. to accept his alternative to being vaccinated.
node.content: ["Aaron Rodgers on Friday spoke publicly for the first time since news broke that he was not vaccinated against the coronavirus and had tested positive, lashing out at the news media and claiming he was a victim of the \u201cwoke mob\u201d and \u201ccancel culture.\u201d", "Rodgers, the Green Bay Packers\u2019 starting quarterback and the N.F.L.\u2019s reigning Most Valuable Player, confirmed he tested positive for the virus after the news rocketed around the sports world on Wednesday. He will miss Green Bay\u2019s game on Sunday against Kansas City and, like all unvaccinated players in the league who test positive, must quarantine for 10 days and test negative in order to return. Vaccinated players can return within 24 hours after they test negative twice, according to protocols jointly agreed upon by the N.F.L. and N.F.L. Players\u2019 Association.", "Rodgers\u2019 comments came on The Pat McAfee Show, a program he attends weekly. During the lengthy interview, Rodgers advocated for personal choice for people\u2019s bodies and criticized vaccine mandates.", "\u201cI\u2019m not some sort of anti-vax, flat-earther,\u201d Rodgers said. \u201cI believe strongly in bodily autonomy and the ability to make choices for your body, not to have to acquiesce to some sort of woke culture or crazed individuals who say you have to do something.\u201d", "Rodgers in August told reporters during training camp that he had been \u201cimmunized\u201d against the virus, a term that the journalists did not press further. On Friday, he said he did not want to take the Pfizer or Moderna vaccines because he had an allergy to an ingredient. He was also hesitant about the Johnson & Johnson vaccine because the Food and Drug Administration recommend to temporarily pause the company\u2019s shot in the spring because of rare instances of blood clots. He also said he was wary of potential effects on fertility, a theory that most medical experts have said is false.", "In consultation with medical advisers, Rodgers said he began an immunization process that the league did not include in its vaccination options. The quarterback petitioned the N.F.L. to approve it \u2014 and said he gathered over 500 pages of research \u2014 but was denied.", "Rodgers said he followed most protocols for unvaccinated players, except for wearing a mask during his weekly news conferences. He also attended a Halloween party maskless with other people, another violation of the protocols.", "Unvaccinated N.F.L. players are subject to more stringent requirements inside and outside of team facilities. They are not supposed to leave hotels when traveling for games, they work out individually in the weight room, and cannot use the sauna or eat with teammates. Rodgers said he was also forced to wear a yellow wristband to identify his status.", "\u201cSome of the rules are not based in science at all,\u201d Rodgers said. \u201cThey\u2019re based purely in trying to out and shame people.\u201d", "\u201cThe great MLK said, \u2018You have a moral obligation to object to unjust rules and rules that make no sense,\u2019\u201d he added, paraphrasing the civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr.", "Davante Adams, the Packers\u2019 leading receiver, and defensive coordinator Joe Barry tested positive for the virus and missed last Thursday\u2019s game against the Arizona Cardinals. The earliest Rodgers could potentially be available is Green Bay\u2019s Week 10 game against the Seattle Seahawks on Nov. 14. Jordan Love, the team\u2019s first-round pick in 2020, will start in Rodgers\u2019s place Sunday against Kansas City.", "The league said in a statement Wednesday that it would review the Packers\u2019 handling of protocols. \u201cThe primary responsibility for enforcement of the Covid protocols within club facilities rests with each club,\u201d N.F.L. spokesman Brian McCarthy said. \u201cFailure to properly enforce the protocols has resulted in discipline being assessed against individual clubs in the past.\u201d"]
